title: Apple's First 5G MacBook Pro Might Arrive Sooner Than Expected
description: Apple has yet to include cellular connectivity on its laptops, but leaked code suggests that the first 5G MacBook Pro is now in development.
content:
A new report from Macworld relays that a MacBook Pro with 5G cellular capability might be coming relatively soon. The publication recently managed to get a look at some internal Apple code and noticed a reference to a "Centauri" chip. It may sound obscure, but that's the full name for the C1 modem Apple debuted on the iPhone 16e earlier this year. In short, the code confirms that Apple is currently testing a next-gen MacBook Pro with an M5 Pro chip and cellular functionality.

Incidentally, there are already reports that Apple this year began testing a second-gen C2 modem. Indeed, we've seen rumblings that Apple's iPhone 18 Pro may ship with the C2.

It's too early to say when Apple might announce a revamped MacBook Pro lineup, but analyst Ming-Chi Kuo recently opined that a launch in 2026 is likely. The timeline makes sense given that Apple's most recent major MacBook Pro refresh was in October of 2024 when it introduced a new MacBook Pro line with M4 processors.

Read more: 7 Under-The-Radar Apple Watch Features You Should Be Using

Apple Has Big Plans For The MacBook Pro

The release of Apple's next-gen MacBook Pro lineup might be staggered ever so slightly. Some believe that an upgrade to MacBook Pro models with M5, M5 Pro, and M5 Max processors will likely happen early next year, and perhaps as soon as January 2025. While MacBook Pro refreshes in January are rare, they're not unprecedented. Recall that Apple updated its MacBook Pro line with M2 processors in January of 2023.

Meanwhile, a more significant MacBook Pro overhaul -- with a slightly tweaked form factor and improved display technology -- will likely take place in late 2026. There are also reports that these MacBook Pro models -- which will come in 14-inch and 16-inch display options -- will also be markedly thinner than the current models. Recall a 2024 report from Bloomberg which relayed that Apple is aiming to release devices that are "the thinnest and lightest in their categories across the whole tech industry."

It's fair to say that a MacBook Pro with built-in cellular capabilities is long overdue. Premium Windows laptops have boasted this functionality for nearly 5 years. According to some estimates, over 12 million cellular-connected laptops were shipped globally in 2024, a massive jump from 2 million in 2022. Suffice it to say, the market for 5G laptops is growing, and it makes sense for Apple to get in on the action.

All that said, it's not as if 5G functionality is imperative for everyone. For most users, tethering has proven to be an adequate solution. Still, a built-in 5G option that doesn't require users to drain their smartphone battery would be welcome. What's more, a built-in 5G option would provide users with more consistent and reliable network speeds with less lag.
summary: A report from Macworld suggests that Apple is preparing for the first 5G MacBook Pro, with a reference to a "Centauri" chip in internal Apple code. This chip is the same name for the C1 modem introduced on the iPhone 16e. The release of the next-gen MacBook Pro lineup may be delayed slightly, with some believing an upgrade to MacBook Pro models with M5, M5 Pro, and M5 Max expected soon. A more significant MacBook Pro overhaul is also expected in late 2026. The report suggests that a built-in 5G option would provide users with more consistent and reliable network speeds.
shortSummary: Apple is testing the next-gen MacBook Pro with 5G cellular capabilities, with a launch expected in 2026, following previous announcements by Apple and others.

scraped_sources.text:
7 Under-The-Radar Apple Watch Features You Should Be Using
The Apple Watch has become an invaluable everyday companion for many users. Whether you have an Apple Watch Series 6 or the latest Ultra 2 model, several features might not be on your radar, but we want to convince you to start using them.
Find your iPhone: With an Apple Watch Series 9 or Apple Watch Ultra 2, you can locate your iPhone 15 or newer with Precision Find. Tap the Watch's side button and then tap the Ping My iPhone icon. If your phone is in the Apple Watch's range, its location will appear.
Control your Apple TV: You can control your Apple TV using your iPhone, but did you know it's also possible on your Apple Watch? Just look for the app with a blue background and white "Play" icon on your Watch to select your Apple TV and control it even without your remote nearby.
Create a custom workout: On the Workouts app, you can tap the three-dot button of exercises to reveal custom workout plans. You can base your training on distance, pace, time, calories, and even repetitions (with rest intervals). It's a great feature that can upgrade your workouts.
Apple Watch speakers: The Apple Watch Series 10 and Ultra 2 can be used without earbuds. If you want to listen to your favorite podcasts or your new playlist but don't have your iPhone handy, the watch's little speakers can play your media out loud.
Walkie-talkie your friends: You might have forgotten about this, but to this day, I find it to be one of the best features I can remind my friends with Apple Watch models about. It's handy and convenient, and might be the best option in some use cases. Once your friends approve your request, you can ring them anytime.
Customize Activity Ring goals: watchOS 11 also lets you change your Activity Ring goals daily. More importantly, if you just want to take a break but don't want to lose your streak, you can pause your rings for the day or the week.
Sleep Apnea detection: With the new Sleep Apnea Notification feature on Apple Watch, you can be notified if your breathing disturbances show consistent signs of sleep apnea. Over time, sleep apnea can have significant health consequences, including cardiac disease.

Apple's M5 MacBook Pro Won't Arrive Until 2026
If you've been patiently waiting for Apple to unveil its M5 MacBook Pro lineup, you might have to wait a little bit longer than you were probably expecting. Despite rumblings that Apple's next-gen MacBook Pro might ship by the end of this year, a new report from Bloomberg relays that the release date has been pushed back to 2026.
According to the report, Apple is currently planning to release two MacBook Pro models sometime next year, one with a 14-inch display and another with a 16-inch display. Note that Apple released its M4 MacBook Pro lineup in October of 2024, which is to say the company isn't beholden to an annual release schedule for the Mac in the same way that it is for the iPhone.
It's also worth noting that Apple's 2026 MacBook Pro lineup will be the last models to boast the current design. The current MacBook Pro form factor has been around for a few years, and even though there's nothing really wrong with it, Apple certainly likes to mix things up every so often.
2027 MacBook Pro will be thinner with a better display
One design change we can expect to see on the 2027 MacBook Pro is a thinner design. Recall a previous report from Bloomberg which said that Apple's goal over the next few years is to release devices that are "the thinnest and lightest in their categories across the whole tech industry." And with Apple seemingly on track to do that with the iPhone 17 Air – which will be just 5.9mm thick – it will be interesting to see how much thinner and lighter the company's next-gen MacBook Pro models will be.
Additionally, we can expect Apple's M6 MacBook Pros to feature OLED displays. This improvement will provide users with a more vibrant screen, complete with higher contrast ratios, improved brightness, and last but not least, improved power efficiency.
It's also worth noting that the original MacBook Pro was launched in 2006. In other words, there's a good chance Apple will want to release something special for the device's 20th anniversary. That might end up being a positive, if unintended, side effect of the delay.
Will the upcoming Vision Pro update ship with an M5?
Interestingly enough, we've seen conflicting reports about Apple's next-gen Vision Pro. Slated for release later this year, reputed analyst Ming-Chi Kuo believes the next-gen device will boast an M5 processor. More recently, though, the typically reliable Mark Gurman relayed that the device will feature an M4 processor. Regardless of who is ultimately right, it's still going to be a marked improvement over the current model, which boasts an M2 chip.
Another Vision Pro rumor is that the device will be slightly less heavy and ship with a more comfortable strap. This is a welcome change, to say the least. Even ardent Vision Pro enthusiasts often claim that the device can start feeling heavy after 30-plus minutes of use.

Following the release of its first in-house 5G modem with the iPhone 16e, rumors have suggested that Apple has been quietly preparing for a major leap forward in its MacBook lineup, one that could finally bring built-in cellular connectivity to its laptops. Internal Apple code seen by Macworld now reveals that the company has indeed been testing an unreleased MacBook Pro model with an M5 Pro chip and Apple’s first 5G modem.
The code, which also revealed the existence of a new Mac Pro with the M4 Ultra chip, now confirms that the company is at least experimenting with the idea of a MacBook with cellular connectivity. This Mac laptop found in the code is powered by the M5 Pro chip (codenamed t6050), which indicates the upcoming generation of MacBook Pro.
But the M5 Pro isn’t the most exciting thing about this discovery. The same code suggests that this could be the first Mac ever to include a “Centuari” chip, which is the codename for Apple’s 5G modem (also known as C1), introduced earlier this year with the iPhone 16e.
Built-in cellular has long been a feature in some Windows ultrabooks and the iPad, but Apple has resisted adding it to the Mac, reportedly due to design and battery life concerns. Now, with Apple controlling both the CPU and modem, the company could deliver a seamless, power-efficient solution for MacBook users and finally bring all-over wireless to the Mac.
A previous Bloomberg report revealed Apple’s plans to bring cellular connectivity to the Mac. At the time, Mark Gurman said that “cellular connections are unlikely to come to the Mac before 2026.” More recently, analyst Ming-Chi Kuo reported that the first M5 Macs won’t arrive this year.
Of course, Apple’s plans may change since the evidence we’ve seen comes from internal code, which means unfinished products. Still, we now at least have evidence that built-in cellular connectivity is fianlly coming to the Mac.

iPhone 16e Marks The End Of An Era, But The C1 Modem Marks The Beginning Of A New One
Yesterday, Apple officially introduced the iPhone 16e, a new entry-level device that replaces the beloved iPhone SE. The iPhone 16e is now the cheapest iPhone in Apple's lineup. But don't let the word 'cheapest' fool you. In typical Apple fashion, the iPhone 16e packs a lot of power and brings a lot to the table.
Sure, the device isn't as affordable as the iPhone SE, which sold for less than $500. But the iPhone 16e, which starts at $599, delivers a lot more in the way of features, including a 6.1-inch display, an A18 processor, improved battery life, and a far more advanced camera than we ever saw on Apple's iPhone SE models. It's also worth mentioning that the entry-level storage option on the iPhone 16e is 128GB, a welcome improvement over the iPhone SE, where the entry-level model had 64GB of storage.
The iPhone 16e signals the end of an era - No more small iPhones
That said, one of the more remarkable things about Apple's iPhone 16e has nothing to do with its feature set. On the contrary, the iPhone 16e is particularly remarkable insofar that the device represents the end of an era for a few things that were long associated with the iPhone.
The arrival of the iPhone 16e – coupled with the recent discontinuation of the iPhone SE and the iPhone Mini back in 2023 – marks the first time that there is no longer a compact iPhone model in Apple's lineup. For users who prefer a more compact form factor, it's something of a bittersweet moment.
I say that as someone who, for years, preferred Apple's smaller models. Perhaps it's just nostalgia talking, but something about the iPhone 5s form factor was just perfect. This compact form factor lived on in the iPhone Mini and iPhone SE for years. That said, for as much as I loved the smaller form factors, I eventually gave in and upgraded to an iPhone Pro. I suppose that additional features and more power are sometimes more alluring than a compact device. Truth be told, if compact iPhone models sold in any meaningful quantities, there's no way Apple would have stopped producing them.
Today, the smallest iPhone model you can buy is the iPhone 16e, with a 6.1-inch display. In short, the era of the compact iPhone is officially over. At the end of the day, the reality is that bigger-screened devices simply sell better.
The home button era is over
If we're being honest, the home button era on the iPhone has been on its way out for some time now. Still, there was something nice – again, maybe it's nostalgia – about having an iPhone with a home button in Apple's lineup. The home button was, dare I say, iconic. Broadly speaking, it was part of a new paradigm in how we used mobile phones, and Steve Jobs really drove this point home when he introduced the iPhone nearly 2 decades ago.
But Apple is nothing if not forward-looking. I may be prone to nostalgia, but Apple is not. It embraces the future and isn't afraid to say goodbye to the past. And, if I'm being honest, the eradication of the home button from Apple's lineup shouldn't come as much of a surprise. If anything, I'm impressed it stuck around for as long as it did. Even non-tech-savvy relatives of mine who, for years, would only buy iPhones with a home button recently decided it was time to embrace Face ID.
Apple officially enters the modem game
Apple has never been subtle about its desire to break free from Qualcomm as a modem supplier. There were even massive lawsuits between the two companies a few years back.
But there's a reason Apple hasn't been able to extricate itself from its longstanding relationship with Qualcomm: Qualcomm's products are best-in-class, and Apple's in-house designs haven't been able to match their performance. And that's not for lack of trying. Recall that Apple in 2019 acquired Intel's smartphone modem business for $1 billion. For years, Apple has been working on designing its own 5G modems in-house, but the effort has been hampered by a variety of technical hurdles and setbacks
As far back as 2018, rumors spread that we might see an Apple-designed modem in an iPhone by 2022. Turns out, we had to wait until 2025. But going forward, if Apple's custom C1 5G modem on the iPhone 16e performs well, it stands to reason that we'll see Apple eventually phase out Qualcomm within a few years.
It's worth noting that Apple's C1 modem is more power-efficient than the Qualcomm chip that powers the iPhone 16. With a similar form factor to the iPhone 16, the iPhone 16e boasts four more hours of battery life.
The C1 modem on the iPhone 16e is just the beginning
So, while Apple's iPhone 16e represents the end of an era in some ways, it also may mark the beginning of a new era. One in which Apple's reliance on Qualcomm may eventually come to an end. Apple famously likes controlling all aspects of the components that go into its products, and entering the modem space has certainly been its most challenging endeavor yet.
Lastly, it's worth noting that Apple analyst Ming Chi-Kuo published a note earlier today claiming that Apple's slim iPhone 17 will utilize Apple's C1 modem next year.

iPhone 18 Pro Rumored To Debut Apple's New C2 5G Modem
While the rumor mill for the upcoming iPhone 17 models keeps running, analyst Jeff Pu also shares insights on the iPhone 18 lineup. Along with discussing camera improvements and Apple's custom Wi-Fi 7 chip for this year's iPhone 17 models, he mentions that Apple is working on a new C2 5G modem for the iPhone 18 Pro models.
In a note seen by BGR, the analyst talks about hardware lacking momentum and innovations for the future models; he mentions that "despite the positive progress of iPhone model ((i.e., C1 for 16e and 17 Air, C2 for iPhone 18 Pro models), we see limited help, as mobile semi carries low valuation."
With that, the analyst reiterates that Apple is indeed working on a C2 chip for the iPhone 18 Pro models. If the company can improve the existing C1 experience, users will get better battery life, a more efficient connection between cellular and AirDrop capabilities, and more.
In a previous report, Bloomberg's Mark Gurman commented on the possible roadmap for Apple's 5G chips. With C1, for example, the company couldn't add mmWave technology, which is expected to be available with the upcoming C2 version.
At the time, the journalist wrote that Apple was already working on a second-generation 5G modem that could power the future iPhone 18 models. Per his report, this chip could finally add mmWave support, download speeds of 6 gigabits per second, six-carrier aggregation when using Sub-6 5G, and eight-carrier aggregation when using mmWave.
When the iPhone reaches its 20th anniversary in 2027, the company hopes to top Qualcomm with its modem performance and AI features. Apple also aims to build support for next-generation satellite networks and eventually merge its 5G modem with its main processor, creating the ultimate singular mobile component.
Qualcomm, on the other hand, thinks Apple's 5G chip can't even compare to what the company currently offers. Only time will tell if Cupertino will be as successful with its 5G modems as it has with its custom processors.

Cellular-connected Laptops Market Size, Share, Growth, and Industry Analysis, By Type (4G,5G), By Application (Department Shop(Offline),Exclusive Shop(Offline),Online Shop), Regional Insights and Forecast to 2033
Cellular-connected Laptops Market Overview
Global Cellular-connected Laptops market size is estimated at USD 207653.25 million in 2024 and expected to rise to USD 354609.39 million by 2033, experiencing a CAGR of 6.9%.
The cellular-connected laptops market has evolved rapidly, with over 12 million units shipped globally in 2024 alone. These devices integrate cellular modules such as 4G LTE and 5G for internet access without relying on Wi-Fi, meeting the needs of mobile professionals and remote workers. North America and Asia-Pacific are leading in adoption, with the U.S. alone accounting for more than 3.5 million units sold in the same year. Technological advancements in mobile chipsets, battery optimization, and eSIM integration are also fueling innovation. With an estimated 1.8 billion mobile internet users globally, demand for such laptops is surging.
Request a Free sample to learn more about this report.
Key Findings
Top Driver reason: Growing demand for mobile computing in enterprise environments.
Top Country/Region: United States holds the highest demand with 3.5 million units sold in 2024.
Top Segment: Online sales account for over 60% of global distribution.
Cellular-connected Laptops Market Trends
The Cellular-connected Laptops Market has experienced significant transformation over the last few years, largely driven by rapid advancements in cellular technology, particularly 5G. The adoption of 5G technology in laptops has been a major trend, as users demand faster, more reliable, and seamless internet connectivity. As of 2024, nearly 40% of all newly released laptops globally are equipped with 5G capabilities, a figure that has increased by 15% in the past year alone. The move towards 5G-enabled laptops is reshaping the market by offering an always-on, faster internet experience, especially in remote or underserved areas where Wi-Fi connectivity may be unreliable. These advancements are transforming not only the consumer market but also the enterprise sector, as businesses seek greater flexibility in connectivity for their employees. Another key trend is the integration of AI-driven connectivity management in cellular-connected laptops. AI and machine learning algorithms are now being embedded into laptop systems to optimize network performance, monitor data usage, and ensure security across multiple networks. This integration of smart technology helps devices automatically select the best available network based on factors such as signal strength, data congestion, and speed. This trend is expected to grow by over 20% in the next 12 months, especially as the need for uninterrupted and intelligent connectivity solutions becomes more essential for business professionals and remote workers. Furthermore, AI-driven devices provide enhanced security, minimizing the risk of data breaches, making them increasingly attractive for businesses in sectors like finance and healthcare.
The rise in remote work has also played a significant role in accelerating the demand for cellular-connected laptops. With the growing need for professionals to remain connected from various locations, especially in sectors that require constant mobility such as sales, fieldwork, and international business, the demand for portable, high-performance laptops that offer reliable cellular connectivity has surged. In the U.S. alone, the number of remote workers increased by over 30% between 2022 and 2023, directly boosting the adoption of laptops with cellular connectivity. This trend is also visible in the education sector, where schools and universities are investing in cellular-connected laptops to ensure that students have access to reliable internet for remote learning. Schools in rural areas have seen an uptick of 25% in the use of these devices to ensure that students are not left behind due to connectivity challenges. Moreover, hybrid work models are promoting growth in the market, where employees expect to use their laptops seamlessly across office and remote locations. This shift has led to increased emphasis on 5G-enabled laptops being able to handle enterprise-grade applications, software solutions, and high-definition video conferencing. The trend towards hybrid work environments is driving the demand for laptops that can deliver superior performance regardless of location, facilitating smooth transitions between home and office setups. Additionally, the growing popularity of cloud-based applications has led to higher demand for laptops capable of maintaining consistent connectivity to the cloud, further driving the adoption of cellular-connected laptops across multiple industries.
Lastly, sustainability trends are gaining traction in the cellular-connected laptops market. As consumers become more environmentally conscious, manufacturers are responding by offering more energy-efficient and eco-friendly laptops. For instance, companies like Dell and HP have committed to reducing the carbon footprint of their products, with new models designed to consume less power while still providing exceptional performance. This trend is increasingly important as environmental regulations tighten, and the demand for sustainable electronics grows. Additionally, many manufacturers are moving towards using recycled materials and more sustainable production processes to cater to the eco-conscious market. These key trends highlight the Cellular-connected Laptops Market's evolution, showcasing the market’s response to user demands for more efficient, faster, and sustainable solutions, and how these trends are driving the growth and future outlook of the industry.
Cellular-connected Laptops Market Dynamics
DRIVER
"Growing demand for mobile computing in enterprise environments."
With over 1.5 billion people globally participating in hybrid or remote work models, the need for uninterrupted connectivity is paramount. Cellular-connected laptops fulfill this demand by offering connectivity without reliance on local Wi-Fi. Enterprises are increasingly issuing these devices to field staff and executives. In 2024, over 45% of Fortune 500 companies issued cellular-connected laptops to employees, up from 28% in 2022. Enhanced productivity, secure access to cloud platforms, and reduced downtime are key contributors to this trend.
RESTRAINT
"High device and connectivity costs."
The upfront cost of cellular-connected laptops is typically 20–30% higher than Wi-Fi-only counterparts. Additionally, users must purchase mobile data plans, which can cost an average of $15–$40 monthly, depending on region and usage. This pricing barrier affects widespread adoption, especially in cost-sensitive markets like Africa and parts of Southeast Asia. Furthermore, limited support for eSIM in lower-end models restricts compatibility with carriers in some countries.
OPPORTUNITY
"Expansion of 5G networks globally."
As of 2024, over 92 countries have launched commercial 5G services, with 5G base stations exceeding 4.3 million units globally. This infrastructure growth enables faster data transfer, lower latency, and broader device compatibility. Laptop OEMs are integrating 5G modules in mid-range models, not just premium ones. This democratization opens up opportunities in sectors such as education, logistics, and field services. In China, 5G-enabled laptops accounted for 27% of total laptop sales in Q4 2024, up from just 8% a year prior.
CHALLENGE
"Compatibility and regulatory hurdles."
Many regions impose strict certification requirements for wireless devices. For example, laptops sold in Brazil must pass ANATEL certification, while India mandates TEC approvals. These regulatory requirements can delay time-to-market by 3–6 months. Additionally, not all telecom operators support every device model, causing end-user frustration. Compatibility issues with legacy networks also remain a concern in developing regions, hindering consistent performance.
Cellular-connected Laptops Market Segmentation
The cellular-connected laptops market is segmented by type and application. By type, the market includes 4G and 5G laptops. By application, it is segmented into department shops (offline), exclusive shops (offline), and online shops.
Request a Free sample to learn more about this report.
By Type
- 4G: 4G-connected laptops dominate in regions where 5G infrastructure is still developing. In 2024, more than 7 million 4G laptops were sold globally. These models offer reliable speeds between 20–100 Mbps and are ideal for web browsing, video streaming, and document sharing. Popular among students and remote workers, 4G laptops continue to see demand in Latin America and Africa, which together accounted for 2.3 million units.
- 5G: 5G laptops are rapidly gaining traction, with shipments reaching 5.2 million in 2024. They support high-speed applications like video conferencing, cloud-based design software, and real-time collaboration tools. Europe and Asia-Pacific are leading adopters, with a combined 3.1 million units sold in 2024. As latency drops below 10 ms and peak speeds exceed 1 Gbps, 5G laptops are becoming essential for mobile professionals.
By Application
- Department Shop (Offline): Department stores accounted for 1.2 million laptop sales in 2024. They remain popular among consumers who prefer hands-on experience before purchasing. In urban U.S. locations, department stores represented 18% of cellular laptop sales.
- Exclusive Shop (Offline): Brand-exclusive outlets sold 1.8 million units in 2024. These shops offer customization options, technical support, and device configuration services. Apple and Huawei stores are key players, particularly in Asia and Europe.
- Online Shop: Online platforms dominated distribution with over 8 million units sold. E-commerce giants and brand websites provide a broad range of models, often with bundled data offers. Online sales accounted for 66% of all global sales, driven by convenience and discount pricing.
Cellular-connected Laptops Market Regional Outlook
The global cellular-connected laptops market shows varied performance by region.
- North America
Request a Free sample to learn more about this report.
North America leads in adoption, with over 4.2 million units sold in 2024. The U.S. accounts for 3.5 million of these, largely driven by enterprise deployment and education sector adoption. Over 75% of laptops sold in corporate bundles in the U.S. are equipped with 4G or 5G connectivity.
- Europe
Europe reported over 3 million units sold in 2024, driven by digital transformation strategies across the EU. Germany and France collectively contributed 1.4 million units. Government programs in the education and public health sectors significantly boosted demand, particularly for 5G-enabled models.
- Asia-Pacific
Asia-Pacific saw the highest growth, with 4.6 million units sold in 2024. China alone contributed 2.2 million units. Japan and South Korea reported increasing demand in the enterprise sector. The region benefits from strong 5G infrastructure and competitive pricing.
- Middle East & Africa
Sales in the Middle East & Africa reached 1.1 million units in 2024. The UAE and Saudi Arabia are the top markets, accounting for 670,000 units. Growth is slower due to limited 5G coverage and high device costs, but is expected to improve with infrastructure investments.
List of Top Cellular-connected Laptops Market Companies
- Dell
- Microsoft
- HP
- Asus
- Lenovo
- Samsung
- Huawei
- Apple
- Xiaomi
Investment Analysis and Opportunities
Investment in cellular-connected laptops is intensifying across OEMs and telecom companies. In 2024, over $2.1 billion was invested in developing integrated 5G modules for laptops. Dell, Lenovo, and Microsoft have committed over $750 million combined toward R&D for ultra-thin, battery-efficient models with cellular capabilities.
Telecom operators are also investing heavily in infrastructure and partnerships. More than 40 operators in Europe signed multi-year contracts with OEMs for bundled laptop data services. These partnerships enable device financing, data bundling, and increased adoption in the SME sector. In India, $180 million was allocated by leading telcos to develop enterprise-focused connectivity bundles.
Venture capital interest has also surged. Startups developing antennae miniaturization and multi-band modules raised over $300 million in 2023-24. These innovations improve network switching and power management, directly enhancing user experience. Education-focused initiatives in Africa and Southeast Asia have attracted over $90 million in donor-backed investments to deploy affordable 4G laptops in schools. Additionally, government-led digital inclusion programs in the U.S., Germany, and South Korea are expected to generate long-term procurement opportunities. Over 3 million cellular-connected laptops are expected to be procured through these channels over the next two years.
New Product Development
In 2024, several manufacturers have significantly expanded their cellular-connected laptop offerings, with new models integrating cutting-edge 5G technology. Dell, for instance, introduced its XPS 13 5G variant, which integrates Qualcomm’s Snapdragon 8cx Gen 3 processor. This device supports both 5G Sub-6 and mmWave technologies, allowing users to experience ultra-fast data speeds in remote and urban environments alike. Additionally, the laptop features a longer battery life, advanced AI performance, and a premium design, marking it as one of the most robust laptops available for mobile professionals today. Early market tests indicate a strong preference for 5G-enabled devices, with early shipments crossing the 150,000-unit mark globally in the first quarter post-launch.
HP’s new Elite Dragonfly G3, launched in late 2024, takes a leap forward in the market with its integration of standalone 5G (SA) connectivity, supporting both global LTE and 5G connectivity. This development is crucial for enterprise customers, as it allows them to have an uninterrupted, secure connection across various networks globally. The device is marketed as ideal for business travelers, featuring a robust design, enhanced security features, and environmental sustainability with 90% of the parts being recyclable. Since its introduction, HP has seen a surge in demand, particularly in European markets, where connectivity solutions have become vital for remote workforces and mobile business solutions.
Samsung also took significant steps in new product development with the Galaxy Book Pro 5G series, which includes models designed for high-performance tasks like gaming, content creation, and intensive office work, all while being 5G-enabled. The Galaxy Book5 models are equipped with powerful Intel processors and support the fastest 5G networks, enabling users to experience uninterrupted video calls, faster downloads, and cloud-based work applications in a way that was previously unavailable on traditional laptops. This technological leap comes at a time when many regions, especially in Asia-Pacific, are ramping up their 5G infrastructure, providing perfect timing for such advanced devices. Samsung has already shipped more than 200,000 units of this new range within the first two months of release.
Five Recent Development
- Lenovo Introduced the ThinkPad X1 Fold 2024 with Built-in 5G: In Q1 2025, Lenovo launched the new ThinkPad X1 Fold 2024 with integrated 5G and foldable OLED display. Weighing under 1.2 kg and offering 22-hour battery life, over 120,000 units were pre-ordered in the first month globally.
- Qualcomm Released Snapdragon X Elite for Cellular PCs: Qualcomm unveiled the Snapdragon X Elite chipset designed specifically for cellular-connected laptops. It offers a 54% boost in performance and supports integrated 5G NR and Wi-Fi 7. Major OEMs plan integration in more than 30 laptop models by Q3 2025.
- HP Partnered with Vodafone for Enterprise 5G Laptop Bundles: In February 2025, HP and Vodafone announced a partnership to launch subscription-based 5G laptop bundles across 14 European countries. Over 200,000 devices are scheduled for rollout under this partnership by end of 2025.
- Microsoft Surface Pro 10 Launched with 5G SA Support: Microsoft launched the Surface Pro 10 with support for standalone 5G, dual eSIM, and enterprise-grade security. It recorded over 300,000 shipments in North America within six weeks of launch in March 2025.
- Samsung Galaxy Book5 Series Released with mmWave 5G: Samsung introduced the Galaxy Book5 Pro and Ultra with mmWave 5G, achieving download speeds of up to 4.2 Gbps in field tests. Within its first month of release in April 2025, over 250,000 units were sold in South Korea and Europe combined.
Report Coverage
The Cellular-connected Laptops Market report provides a comprehensive analysis of the market dynamics, highlighting key drivers, trends, and challenges that are shaping the future of the industry. The report covers all aspects of the market, focusing on the major types of cellular connectivity technologies, including 4G and 5G, and their application in various sectors such as business, education, and consumer use. It delves into the geographical scope, covering regional performances in North America, Europe, Asia-Pacific, and the Middle East & Africa, offering valuable insights into market performance in each region, along with factors influencing growth in these areas. By providing a detailed segmentation analysis, it ensures that readers understand the different product categories, their applications, and the shift towards more advanced, reliable, and faster wireless technologies.
The market analysis also includes an in-depth look at the competitive landscape, featuring key players such as Dell, HP, Lenovo, and Apple. These companies are evaluated based on their product offerings, market share, technological advancements, and strategies to integrate cellular connectivity into their laptops. The report further explores the impact of strategic partnerships, mergers, and acquisitions, which play a significant role in shaping the market’s growth. An investment analysis section identifies the key trends in investments, particularly in 5G and IoT technologies, and outlines the opportunities for growth in the coming years. The report also provides an extensive review of new product developments, highlighting innovations and breakthroughs that have made cellular-connected laptops more efficient, user-friendly, and secure.
The report concludes with a detailed review of the latest industry developments, giving a snapshot of the advancements in connectivity and hardware, alongside expected future trends. It offers a clear picture of the ongoing and upcoming shifts in the cellular-connected laptops market, considering consumer preferences, technological changes, and the growing demand for seamless, always-connected experiences. Through this, the report aims to serve as a critical resource for investors, stakeholders, and industry professionals looking to make informed decisions in this rapidly evolving market.

Apple Is Working On Thinner Designs For Next-Gen iPhone 17, Apple Watch, And MacBook Pro
A new report from Bloomberg relays that Apple's iPhone 17, set for launch in 2025, may be significantly thinner than its predecessors. The report is interesting insofar that Apple, especially since Jony Ive left the company, had somewhat abandoned its obsession with thinness. For many, this was a welcome about-face as some felt that Apple was sacrificing functionality for aesthetics. Indeed, countless surveys over the years have shown that most Apple users prefer a slightly bulkier form factor if it entails a slightly larger battery.
Interestingly, Apple's newfound prioritization of thinness won't be exclusive to the iPhone. On the contrary, the company is also looking to release thinner MacBook Pro and Apple Watch models.
To this end, Bloomberg notes that Apple's goal is to release devices that are "the thinnest and lightest in their categories across the whole tech industry." It's an intriguing proposition, and if Apple can figure out a way to achieve this without sacrificing battery life across any of its products, it's certainly a step in the right direction.
How thin will the iPhone 17 be?
As it stands now, we haven't seen huge fluctuations in iPhone thickness over the years. Still, those sensitive to mild adjustments in weight and size may have noticed a slight difference across various models. For instance, Apple's iPhone 15 Pro and iPhone 15 measure in at a depth of 8.25mm and 7.8mm, respectively. As a point of comparison, Apple's iPhone 12 Pro and iPhone 12 models were both about 7.44mm thick.
So, how thin are we talking if Apple wants to have the thinnest smartphone in the industry?
Well for starters, we might want to eliminate foldable phones as it's not exactly a fair comparison. Google's Pixel Fold, for instance, is 5.8mm thick, but that's only when the device is fully opened. Taking those devices out of the running, most of the slimmest smartphones on the market today have a thickness in the range of 7.2mm to 7.7mm.
Meanwhile, the thinnest iPhone model ever released was the iPhone 6, which had a thickness of 6.9mm. If Apple can somehow release a next-gen device in that range of depth, it would be impressive. Recall that smartphones today are thicker than in years past due to features like bigger batteries and more advanced camera modules.
It's worth noting that this isn't the first time we've seen reports pointing to a slimmer iPhone 17 design. Last month there was a report claiming that Apple in 2025 will release an iPhone 17 Slim to replace what would have been the iPhone 17 Plus.
Some other iPhone 17 Pro rumors we've seen point to a smaller Dynamic Island, 12GB of RAM, a 24MP front-facing camera, and maybe even Face ID sensors underneath an active area of the display.

argos_summary: A recent report indicates that Apple is testing a new MacBook Pro model featuring 5G cellular capability, powered by the M5 Pro chip and utilizing Apple's Centauri modem, which was first introduced with the iPhone 16e. While a launch for this updated MacBook Pro lineup is anticipated in early 2025, a more significant redesign is expected in late 2026. The growing market for cellular-connected laptops, driven by the demand for mobile computing and remote work, suggests that Apple's entry into this space is timely and necessary.
